Dear Nicole Lynn Gillies:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 5/3/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement
• (3) An agency shall document review of the
foster parent/agency agreement with the foster
family at least annually and, when needed,
develop a new agreement.
Three of three open foster home files reviewed did not contain documentation
that annual review of Foster Parent/Agency Agreement with the family occurred.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and
make a licensing recommendation to the
department at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration date of the foster home license.
One of three open foster home files reviewed contained a renewal inspection
report that was not completed and approved at least 15 days prior to the license
expiration.

CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (4) Before completion of the written report
required by subrule (6) of this rule, an agency
shall provide the foster parent with a verbal
summary of the preliminary findings at the
conclusion of the evaluation.
One of three special evaluation reports reviewed documented that the verbal
summary of preliminary findings was provided to the family prior to the conclusion
of the investigation.
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement
• (2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in
independent living.
One of one open file of a youth in independent living placement reviewed did not
contain documentation that the youth was provided the agency's independent
living program's program statement prior to entry into the program.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
• (3) An agency shall provide a youth in
independent living with a copy of the agency's
policies and procedures required by this rule.
One of one open file of a youth in independent living placement reviewed did not
contain documentation that the youth was provided the agency's independent
living program's policies and procedures prior to entry into the program.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by
the youth and the social service worker. The
agreement must be reviewed with the youth at
least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of one open file of a youth in independent living placement reviewed did not
contain any independent living agreements signed by the youth and worker.

CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
• (1) An agency social service worker shall
complete a written adoptive evaluation within 90
days of the family signing an adoption
application and prior to approving a family for
adoption.
Two of three adoptive family files reviewed contained adoptive family evaluations
not completed within 90 days of the signed application.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 5/5/2022, CAP Approved 5/26/2022
Interim 5/12/2023, CAP Approved 6/5/2023
SRM 200 FINGERPRINTS
Electronic CWCHRI Media
Electronic CW-CHRI Media must be secured through
encryption as specified in the CJIS Security Policy.
The electronic case management system and CCWIS
Secure Criminal History Section is the only approved
electronic system to store CW-CHRI.
One of three adoptive family files reviewed contained CHRI information within the
electronic record saved outside of the Secure Criminal History portion of the
record.
ADM 300 CHILD ADOPTION ASSESSMENT
The DHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment, must be
completed by the adoption worker and approved by the
adoption supervisor within 45 calendar days of case
acceptance.
One of three open youth adoption files reviewed contained a Child Adoption
Assessment completed more than 45 days past the acceptance date.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 5/5/2022, CAP Approved 5/26/2022

ADM 330 QUARTERLY ADOPTION PROGRESS REPORTS
Adoption workers must submit written quarterly
progress reports using the DHS-614, Quarterly
Adoption Progress Report.The child adoption
assessment may serve as the initial quarterly report if it
is completed within the required quarterly reporting
period and attached to the DHS-614 form.
Note: When the child adoption assessment is used as
the initial quarterly report, the next quarterly report is
due 90 calendar days from completion of the child
adoption assessment. When the child adoption
assessment is not completed within the initial required
quarterly reporting period, the DHS-614 is due 90
calendar days from case acceptance or 90 days after
the order terminating parental rights is signed,
whichever is later.
One of three open youth adoption files reviewed did not contain all quarterly
adoption assessments.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 5/5/2022, CAP Approved 5/26/2022
ADM 980 ADOPTION CLOSING SUMMARY (DHS-222)
A copy of the closing summary must be sent within 14
calendar days of the adoption finalization date to the
foster care worker and the Department of Health and
Services (DHHS) adoption monitor for purchase of
service cases for inclusion in the child’s permanent
record. The DHS-222, Adoption Closing Summary
must be used for this purpose.
One of Ttwo closed youth adoption files reviewed contained an Adoption Closing
Summary not completed within 14 calendar days of the finalization date.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 5/5/2022, CAP Approved 5/26/2022
Interim 5/12/2023, CAP Approved 6/5/2023

FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each
placement.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed
parties is documented in the electronic case
management record by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
One of three open files of youth in foster care placements reviewed did not
contain a medical passport signed by the caregiver at replacement.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• There was no technical assistance requested or required.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Independent Living is a placement type, not a legal status; therefore, when
YAVFC youths are living independently, the independent living licensing rules
must be followed.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The one
CAP submitted by the agency was in response to the 2023 interim licensing
inspection and was approved on 6/5/2023. That agency addressed 8 non-
compliances within that CAP, 5 of which were addressed successfully as
evidenced by those non-compliances not being repeated during this year's
inspection. Three of the noncompliances addressed in that CAP were repeated
this year (medical passports, adoptive family evaluation timeliness, and adoption
closing summary timeliness) and will require additional corrective action planning
to address why the previous actions taken were not effective.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment identified areas of the previously submitted
and approved CAP that were not successful, such as the document/checklist
implemented to assist in improving timeliness of adoption reports. Additionally, the
chief administrator identified challenges with rule/policy compliance due to staff
performance issues that have been addressed through documented corrective
action as well as failure on the part of staff to obtain and upload documents timely.
The Chief Administrator indicated the previous CAP was effective, resulting in no
further incidents of non-compliance, in areas such as confidentiality, medical
passports, PATP signatures, and family team meetings. The only discrepancy
found during this inspection was related to medical passports as one file did not
contain a replacement medical passport signed by the caregiver timely. During the
exit meeting it was determined the foster care supervisor misunderstood the
timeframe requirement for this document; therefore, the noncompliance was not
identified internally.
Financial Overview
The agency's budget, financial statements, and independent auditor's report were
reviewed, and no concerns were identified.
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via video conferencing. One staff
reported she will be leaving the agency soon but did not express any concerns
with the agency. All three staff reported receiving regular and frequent supervision
and stated the program director provides timely information and trainings related
to policy and rule changes/updates. No concerns were identified by any of the
interviewed staff.

Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency has adequate space and office equipment to perform the required
functions of foster care, licensing, adoption, and independent living services. Files
and physical CHRI are stored securely in a manner that prevents unauthorized
access. There is a cross shredder located in the main building.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
